Hopkins Defense Shows Up Well —Crescents Shift Positions Often—Baxley
Shoots Both Goals For Varsity.
Body Checking Barred.

The Varsity Lacrosse Team
closed its season by playing the
Crescent Athletic Club a 2-2 tie
at Brooklyn last Saturday afternoon. Although the Crescents
have lost a good many men
through enlistments, they had
their best team of the season out
Saturday, including their old
stars, Wall, Dobby, Kennady, and
O'Rourke. The Black and Blue
played good lacrosse, the defense
playing an especially steady game
but they were greatly handicapped
by the referee's refusing to allow
body checking. Several of the
Crescents were beautiful dodgers,
but quick work in intercepting by
the close defense, and some pretty
stops by Sadtler, stopped many
good shots. The Crescents juggled their men's positions continually, Bob Wall shifting once
from point to inhome; Kennady
played three or four positions before the game was over. This
kept the Hopkins defense always
on the look out for unexpected extra men, but Schmidt and Meyer
did some beautiful work in breaking up their plays.
Hopkins scored the first goal in
the first minute of play, the ball
going straight down the field to
Baxley, who shot from near the
crease. Wardell evened it up for
the Crescents a few moments later.
From then till the end of the half
it was back and forth, up and
down the field, the ball most of
the time in Hopkins' possession.
Baxley scored Hopkins' second
point from a mix-up in front of
goal at the beginning of the second half.
The Black and Blue then settled
down and played splendidly, and
it looked for a while as though
Hopkins would get away with the
game. But O'Rourke finally got
the ball, and running around
thirty yards outside of goal, got
off a quick, twisting shot which
got by Sadtler. From then on the
game was very rough, both teams
fighting their hardest to break the
tie. Men were put out for periods
on both sides, but the whistle blew
before either team could score
again. Hopkins wanted to play
an extra period; and would have
stood a good chance of winning
had they been able to play longer,
for the team was going finely at
the end.

How can I best serve my country? That is the all-important
question; it has often been answered by the President and the War
Department. It is once more answered in an article concerning the
new "Enlisted Training Corps" for college students, which quotes
President Wilson's statement that "it would seriously impair America's prospects of success in this war if the supply of highly trained
men were unneccessarily diminished."
The War Departnient, to aid in averting this evil, has instituted
a plan whereby all R. 0. T. C. men of eighteen or over will next year
be members of the Army of the United States, liable to active duty
at the call of the President. One of the main objects of this scheme
is "to prevent unnecessary and wasteful depletion of the colleges
through indiscriminate volunteering, by offering to the students a
definite and immediate military status." The wish, then, of your
government, college men, is for you to continue your education and
become an officer or at least a highly trained man. Though the
soldier's life with its glamor is not immediately entered upon, the
greatest service you can render your country is to enlist in this new
R. 0. T. C. Let us hope that next year every physically fit undergraduate will enroll in this branch of the service.
. In regard to those who fail to avail themselves of an opportunity to return to college, merely because they are making "good
money," we would say that such a course is unwise to the highest
degree. Work this summer by all means and give the best that is
in you, but do not let the lure of the present high salaries draw you
from your duty at college, where you can get that military knowledge and scientific training needed so much by the government.
Moreover, after the war the large salaries are obliged to decrease,
because of the falling off in demand for and the increase in supply
of this kind of labor. Then the man who has left college will fully
appreciate his lack of training, for instead of holding plates in position for the riveter he might have been drawing plans for ships.

INSPECTOR PRAISES BATTALION
In Detailed Report Lieut. R. Kelly Lauds
Discipline and Appearance of Battalion—Mentions Particularly Work
of Faculty Staff Officers.

First Lieut. Robert F. Kelly, of
the 22nd Infantry, made a most
favorable report to the Government in regard to the courses in
military science given at the.Johns
Hopkins University this year. The
report contains no adverse criticism; it iQ one which reflects
credit on every one who is connected directly or indirectly with
the military work done here.
The government inspector asserted that a very high degree of
importance is attached to the military instruction, that the officer
on duty is vigorously supported
by the faculty, and that the military professor is quite satisfactory to the authorities of this institution.
The Battalion members were
highly complimented in his report
for the manner in which they
maintained a very severe discipline, and zealously performed
their military duties.
The following quotations serve
to give one an idea of how the
R. 0. T. C. unit of this University
impressed the Inspector:
"Q. 8. With what degree of zeal
is military duty performed? A.

The Varsity Lacrosse Team
closed its season by playing the
Crescent Athletic Club a 2-2 tie
at Brooklyn last Saturday afternoon. Although the Crescents
have lost a good many men
through enlistments, they had
their best team of the season out
Saturday, including their old
stars, Wall, Dobby, Kennady, and
O'Rourke. The Black and Blue
played good lacrosse, the defense
playing an especially steady game
but they were greatly handicapped
by the referee's refusing to allow
body checking. Several of the
Crescents were beautiful dodgers,
but quick work in intercepting by

going straight down the field to

crease. Wardell evened it up for
the Crescents a few moments later.

it was back and forth, up and
down the field, the ball most of
the time in Hopkins' possession.
Baxley scored Hopkins' second
point from a mix-up in front of
goal at the beginning of the second half.

down and played splendidly, and
it looked for a while as though
Hopkins would get away with the
game. But O'Rourke finally got
the ball, and running around
thirty yards outside of goal, got
off a quick, twisting shot which

game was very rough, both teams
fighting their hardest to break the
tie. Men were put out for periods
on both sides, but the whistle blew
before either team could score

How can I best serve my country? That is the all-important
question; it has often been answered by the President and the War
Department. It is once more answered in an article concerning the
new "Enlisted Training Corps" for college students, which quotes
President Wilson's statement that "it would seriously impair America's prospects of success in this war if the supply of highly trained
men were unneccessarily diminished."
The War Departnient, to aid in averting this evil, has instituted
a plan whereby all R. 0. T. C. men of eighteen or over will next year
be members of the Army of the United States, liable to active duty
at the call of the President. One of the main objects of this scheme
is "to prevent unnecessary and wasteful depletion of the colleges
through indiscriminate volunteering, by offering to the students a
definite and immediate military status." The wish, then, of your
government, college men, is for you to continue your education and
become an officer or at least a highly trained man. Though the
soldier's life with its glamor is not immediately entered upon, the
greatest service you can render your country is to enlist in this new
R. 0. T. C. Let us hope that next year every physically fit undergraduate will enroll in this branch of the service.

degree. Work this summer by all means and give the best that is
in you, but do not let the lure of the present high salaries draw you
from your duty at college, where you can get that military knowledge and scientific training needed so much by the government.

because of the falling off in demand for and the increase in supply
of this kind of labor. Then the man who has left college will fully
appreciate his lack of training, for instead of holding plates in position for the riveter he might have been drawing plans for ships.

[From the Patriotic News Service]

For nearly a year there has been
much public discussion of the
proper function of colleges and of
the duty of college students in the
present emergency. Last July
President Wilson said:
"It would seriously impair
America's prospects of success in
this war if the supply of highly
trained men were unnecessarily
diminished. There will be need
for a larger number of persons
expert in the various fields of applied science than . ever before.
* * * * * I therefore have
no hesitation in urging colleges
and technical schools to endeavor
to maintain their courses as far
as possible on the usual basis.
* * * * * Those who fall below the age of selective conscription and who do not enlist may
feel that by pursuing their courses
with earnestness and diligence
they also are preparing themselves
for valuable services to the Nation."
• The vital contribution of the
colleges is now formally recognized in an announcement just issued by the Secretary of War. As
a military measure the colleges of
the country are by this announcement officially designated as training centers for the United States
Army. The announcement follows:
"In order to provide military
instruction for the college students of the country during the
present emergency, a comprehensive plan will be put in effect by
the War Department, beginning
with the next college year, in September, 1918. The details remain
to be worked out, but in general
the plan will be as follows:
"Military instruction under officers and non-commissioned officers
of the army will be provided in
every institution of college grade,
which enrolls for the instruction
100 or more able-bodied students
over the age of eighteen. The necessary military equipment will,
so far so possible, be provided by
the Government. There will be
created a military training unit
in each institution. Enlistment
will be purely voluntary but all
students over the age of eighteen
will be encouraged to enlist. The
enlistment will constitute the student a member of the Army of the
United States, liable to active
duty at the call of the President.
It will, however, be the policy of
the Government not to call the
members of the training units to
active duty until they have
